description:
Acanthamoeba healyi is a species of free-living amoeba that belongs to the genus Acanthamoeba. It is a microscopic, single-celled organism that is commonly found in various environmental sources, such as soil, water, and air.

Acanthamoeba healyi is characterized by the presence of distinct, spike-like projections called acanthopodia on its surface, which it uses for locomotion and prey capture. The amoeba has a life cycle that includes a trophozoite stage, where it is actively feeding and reproducing, and a cyst stage, which is a dormant and resistant form that allows the organism to survive in unfavorable environmental conditions.

This species is considered to be an opportunistic pathogen, as it can cause a rare but severe infection known as Acanthamoeba keratitis, which primarily affects the cornea of the eye. Acanthamoeba healyi has been identified as one of the causative agents of this infection, particularly in individuals who wear contact lenses or have experienced eye injuries.

Due to its ability to survive in a wide range of environmental conditions and its potential to cause serious human infections, Acanthamoeba healyi is an important subject of study in the fields of microbiology, parasitology, and public health.
